Posts.Content: May 24, 2017 08:59PM RoseRN1 wrote: I would try to buy cheap bras to wear to radiation. They marked me up with a sharpie the other day, needless to say my bra has all the black spots. You can find some cheap bras at Kmart or Walmart. I suggest go up a size in width and cup size in case you swell
Posts.Title: Starting Radiation in May 2017 Tappermom383 smarchez

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2017 09:29PM RoseRN1 wrote: Badornettp you will have to be topless for rads. I just wear jeans and a large top. I've been wearing a larger size bra (when I wear one) and a larger size top, just to be comfortable. My nipple and areola have been swelling and sensitive . I change into a hospital gown and naked from waist up, but gown comes off when I get into the room because I get my regular radiation face down with my breast dangling down thru a hole in the table. My boost will be supine. Some wear their gowns backwards and just untie it for the rads . FYI lanolin is great for nipple issues

My skin in general on my boob looks pretty good though. Hopefully next week will start back at the gym. Goincrazy8, the boost was easier on my breast, so not as bad, but keep applying lotion and drink a lot

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2017 09:20PM RoseRN1 wrote: toppermom, i've had fungus under breast, especially if you go to gym a lot. For me it's due to having large breast and sweating. They usually give nystatin cream or powder to use. I do Dove unscented for sensitive skin, but concerned because it contains a moisturizers and afraid it would be too moist. Also try to expose your breast to air as much as you can renee, let them know you are getting pink this soon. I just started to burn the other day, but with the silvadene and steroids it looks so much better. Today was #25 so last of entire breast rads. Monday will start the first of 5 boosts!

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2017 09:14PM RoseRN1 wrote: 3bears, i too am stage 1 with no nodes grade 3. I go to see MO tomorrow. I am 61 years young. My oncotyoe was 27. At first, my BS said anyone with a score over 25 should have chemo, but then said the study compares it to Tamoxifen. She said the other AI drugs are much more effective than Tamoxifen, so my risk of recurrence was lower and I wouldn't be on tamoxifen. I think with chemo, the percent would only change to 4% so risks would outweigh benefits. She is not an oncologist so waiting to hear what MO says

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2017 08:09PM RoseRN1 wrote: This disease just sucks! Everyone need time to absorb what has happened and then to focus on the tough journey ahead. Don't waste too much of your precious energy for too long a time, focusing on negative things. I was a nurse for 20 years...An oncology nurse at that! I left the hospital scene about 20 years ago and it's amazing how things have changed. There are always new treatments coming out. Who knows, maybe during our time here, someone will actually discover something that works that doesn't have all these horrid side effects. I had my 'chemo' class today and start my chemo journey next week. I'm one of the lucky ones. I only need 4 rounds every 3 weeks. You can do it!
